Joe,

May not be relevant to this thread but to your posting.

Can I do par=
tial comparison using XMLUnit?  What I mean is check
<firstname> and <lastn=
ame> and ignore/skip the rest type of
comparison.

~JAK

On 5/6/05, J. B. R=
ainsberger <jbrains@...> wrote:
>  Jyoti wrote:
>  > Hi,
>  > 
>  > =
  I am a QA person with some java knowledge. I am testing some API's
>  > b=
y passing XML as input with different values to Web Services.Tools
>  > use=
d to buid the application are Web Logic 8.1,J2EE
>  > 
>  > I need to autom=
ate this testing with JUNIT, can anyone suggest how
>  > and from where to =
start.
>  > 
>  >   Example - I am using a webservice createStudent -- and =
passing the
>  > XML like this
>  > 
>  > <StudentBIZ>
>  >     <cus:studen=
tName>abc</cus:studentName>
>  >     <cus:password>pass</cus:password>
>  >=
     <cus:email>abc@...</cus:email>
>  >     <cus:firstname>cc</cus:fir=
stname>
>  >     <cus:lastName>cc</cus:lastName>
>  > </StudentBIZ>
>  > 
>=
  > which returns an XML to me giving the student info.
>  
>  XMLUnit allo=
ws you to verify XML documents. I suggest trying it. If you 
>  know XPath,=
 then you know enough to check each part of the student info 
>  XML you ge=
t back for each test. Even if you don't know XPath, you can 
>  write asser=
tions like this:
>  
>  String expectedXml =3D "<StudentInfo> ... </Student=
Info>";
>  assertXMLEqual(expectedXml, myWebService.getResponse(inputXml));=

>  
>  XMLUnit is smart enough to ignore simple differences like whitespac=
e.
>  
>  Good luck.
